articles.title: Adamawa govt, NEMA sensitise stakeholders on 2025 flood risks
articles.author: Amos
articles.summary: The Adamawa State Emergency Management Agency (ADSEMA) and the NEMA have launched a sensitisation campaign to address 2025 flood risks and promote coordinated responses to mitigate climate change effects in the state. The focus is on communities along the banks of Rivers Benue and Gongola and their basins. The district head of Jimeta commended the flood control initiatives.

articles.title: Reducing climate impact on human health
articles.author: 单学英
articles.summary: Climate change is increasing the spread of communicable diseases and indirectly altering vectors. WHO spearheads the "Alliance for Transformative Action on Climate and Health" to provide targeted support for health ministries of countries. WHO has been urging countries to integrate health adaptation measures into their climate-action strategy and allot more funds to combat climate change. COP28 was a milestone as it held the first "Health Day" and adopted the "COP28 UAE Declaration on Climate & Health".

articles.title: Arson at Aldi: Melbourne police search for man who set fire at store under construction
articles.author: J.D. Gallop
articles.summary: A fire was deliberately set at a Melbourne, Florida Aldi store under construction. The suspect remains at large and the motive for the fire is unknown. The fire was reported about 10:40 a.m. May 25 at the new Aldi supermarket being built in the 900 block of East Eau Gallie Boulevard.

articles.title: Australia is Collapsing
articles.author: ∙ Paid
articles.summary: Australia is slowly being dismantled through deliberate policy, cultural sabotage, and institutional decay. The same blueprint is being applied in America, Britain, Canada and beyond. If they can break Australia, they can also break any of us. Greg Sheridan's column ' Australia divided, misgoverned, in retreat: our nation in decline' in The Weekend Australian reveals how Australia is becoming the West's warning sign.

articles.title: Delayed pollen season hits allergy sufferers hard
articles.summary: A warmer-than-usual start to spring has caused pollen levels to rise significantly across British Columbia. Seasonal allergies are hitting some residents harder than ever. Sohrab Sandhu reports on the rise in pollen levels in British Columbia from Sohrab Sandhu.

articles.title: Penguin Poop May Help Counteract Climate Change
articles.author: Kate Seamons
articles.summary: Ammonia released from penguin droppings may help cool Antarctica by boosting cloud formation. Researchers measured air near Marambio Base between January and March 2023. When winds came from the direction of a colony of Adelie penguins 5 miles away, the ammonia concentration skyrocketed.

articles.title: Snowy owl's threatened status an 'alarm bell' for a changing Arctic, scientist says
articles.author: News Staff
articles.summary: The Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife In Canada recommended a change of status for the emblematic northern snowy owl, which is also Quebec's official bird. The federal government will decide whether to list the snowy owl as threatened under the Species at Risk Act. Snowy owl observations have declined about 40 per cent over the last three generations, or 24 years.

articles.title: Snowy owl's threatened status an 'alarm bell' for a changing Arctic, scientist says
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: The committee's recommendation should be a 'rallying cry' to accelerate efforts to protect Canada's biodiversity. Climate change reduces sea ice, which the birds use for resting and hunting, increased shrub cover in the wide-open tundra habitat where the owl breeds, and there have been suggestions the population cycles of lemmings — its main prey — are being affected. Quebec has yet to begin its own formal process to assess the status of its official bird.

articles.title: Panthers can sweep their way back to Stanley Cup Final with a win over Hurricanes on Monday night
articles.author: TIM REYNOLDS
articles.summary: Brad Marchand and the Florida Panthers lead the Carolina Hurricanes 3-0 in the Eastern Conference finals. Florida is on the brink of reaching the Stanley Cup Final. It would be the Panthers' third straight appearance in that round and Marchand's first time in the title round since 2019.

articles.title: Rohingya refugees at the mercy of climate change
articles.author: Dr. Azeem Ibrahim
articles.summary: Rohingya, a persecuted Muslim minority from Myanmar, are living in overcrowded refugee camps in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh. More than a million Rohingya have fled genocide and violence in Rakhine State since 2017, seeking refuge in the refugee camps. The camps are increasingly vulnerable to climate change, cyclones, floods and earthquakes, while rising sea levels shrink Bangladesh's landmass. The UN's Joint Response Plan for the Rohingya was only 37 percent funded in 2024.

articles.title: Rising seas to test humanity even at 1.5°C
articles.summary: Rising seas will severely test humanity's resilience in the second half of the 21st century and beyond. The pace at which global oceans are rising has doubled in three decades and on current trends will double again by 2100 to about 1cm per year. An additional 20cm of sea level rise by 2050 would cause some $1 trillion in flood damage annually in the world's 136 largest coastal cities.

articles.title: Melting Antarctica is key to region's sea level rise, says BAS marine geophysicist in Cambridge talk
articles.summary: Rob Larter is a marine geophysicist working at British Antarctic Survey. He gave a talk to Friends of the River Cam on 21 May 2025 about the changing West Antarctic Ice Sheet and its implications for East Anglia. The talk reflected Rob's work on 17 Antarctic and sub-Antarctic research cruises, including eight where he was chief scientist.

articles.title: It is in the West's interest to prevent nations' climate destruction – as well as its duty
articles.author: Editorial
articles.summary: The rich countries should do more to help the poor to mitigate the effects of climate change, writes ODI Global. Since 2000, 53 low-income countries have suffered $395bn in losses and damages from extreme weather events, some $156bn of which can be attributed to climate change.

articles.title: Florida bill would ban ‘chemtrails' and ‘geoengineering.' But what are they?
articles.author: Martin E. Comas
articles.summary: Gov. Ron DeSantis recently said he'd sign into law a ban on 'weather modification activities' such as spreading tiny particles into the air from aircraft to control sunlight. It raised long-standing controversies over 'geoengineering' and 'chemtrails'.

articles.title: Florida bill would ban ‘chemtrails' and ‘geoengineering.' But what are they?
articles.author: Martin E. Comas
articles.summary: Gov. Ron DeSantis recently said he'd sign into law a ban on 'weather modification activities' such as spreading tiny particles into the air from aircraft to control sunlight. It raised long-standing controversies over 'geoengineering' and 'chemtrails'.

articles.title: From Ice To Ocean: Glacier Melt Fuels India's Extreme Weather
articles.summary: Glaciers are central to today's climate crisis, driving extreme weather worldwide. Global warming is up by 1.1°C since pre-industrial times, accelerates glacial melt in Greenland, Antarctica, and the Himalayas. In India, Himalayan glacial retreat intensifies sea-level rise, flooding, and cyclones along the Bay of Bengal and Arabian Sea. A 50 cm rise by 2050 could inundate 20% of low-lying areas, including the Sundarbans, displacing millions and threatening biodiversity. Global emission reductions, robust sea walls, mangrove restoration, and climate-resilient agriculture are essential.

articles.title: Rising Tides: Making a More Resilient Lowcountry - A News 4 Special
articles.author: Sonya Stevens
articles.summary: Coastal flooding is increasing due to climate change. Charleston has seen over a foot of sea level rise in the last century. Sullivan's Island and Isle of Palms are more vulnerable to beach erosion. The Army Corps of Engineers used beneficial reuse of sediment from Intracoastalway to shore up the beach.

articles.title: Strong winds the next challenge for flood-ravaged towns
articles.author: Maeve Bannister
articles.summary: Flood-ravaged communities begin a lengthy clean-up. Bad weather threatens further challenges to coastal areas, as it has already affected some areas.      Â   yestendereffects of the bad weather are still to come.

articles.title: Ready for hurricane season?
articles.author: Michael Bates
articles.summary: Last year, Citrus County was hit by three hurricanes, Debby, Helene and Milton. Now, the county is taking steps to prepare for the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season, when it's expected to hit the area again.    .

articles.title: The Guardian view on rising sea levels: adaptation has never been more urgent
articles.author: Editorial
articles.summary: In the 17th-century Dutch golden age, the biblical story of Noah's ark resonated in a culture where catastrophic floods were an ever-present threat. The history of the Netherlands includes multiple instances of storms breaching dikes, leading to disastrous losses of life and land. As with the other damage caused by rising global temperatures, neither the risks nor resources to deal with them are evenly shared out. Around 230 million people live within 1 metre above the current sea level.

articles.title: Haiti - Port-de-Paix : Towards integrated management of the Haut-Fourneau mangrove ecosystem - HaitiLibre.com : Haiti news 7/7
articles.summary: As part of International Biodiversity Day, the Northwest Departmental Directorate of the Ministry of the Environment organized an environmental sectoral roundtable on the theme "Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation: Towards the Implementation of an Integrated Management Plan for the Haut-Fourneau Mangrove Ecosystem". This initiative is financially supported by the "Global Climate Change Alliance" (GCCA+ Haiti) project through the Climate Change Directorate. It aims to strengthen consultation between institutional, community, technical, and economic stakeholders.

articles.title: Toxic Fungi Could Threaten Millions of Lives Within 15 Years
articles.author: Darren Orf
articles.summary: There are only about 10 percent of species of fungi on Earth, so unknown surprises would be in store as fungi spread beyond their historic regions. Life-sustaining fungi that break down plant and animal matter could be at risk of extinction in some of the warmest regions of the Earth, especially on the African continent. If the world still relies on mostly fossil fuels instead of clean energy, fungi like Aspergillus flavus will spread by 16 percent within 15 years and put an additional 1 million people at risk in Europe.

articles.title: Vulnerable to climate change, UAE breaches May temperature record  AW
articles.summary: The highest temperature in the UAE on Saturday was 51.6 degrees Celsius in Sweihan. It was 50.4 degrees Celsius a day earlier in Dubai. The UAE has just emerged from a record-breaking April with an average daily high of 42.6 degree Celsius. The desert nation lies in one of the planet's hottest regions.

articles.title: Global Warming? You Can't Get There from Here.
articles.author: Thomas J Shepstone
articles.summary: There is no such thing as a global temperature. Hyperbole or citation of specific weather events or tempertures here or there on some specific date mean nothing, but you can't get there from what we read every day in the press. Back in the 1930s, people were talking about the weather in Australia, Wisconsin and the southwest United States.

articles.title: Revealed: The true cost of climate crisis for world's poorest countries
articles.author: Alicja Hagopian
articles.summary: Since 2000, the world's poorest countries have suffered $395 billion in losses and damages from extreme weather events. 17,000 deaths can be directly attributed to climate change. The nations hardest hit are Somalia, Haiti and Uganda. The figures come after Donald Trump slashed US aid spending and the UK is planning on cutting billions of pounds in funding.

articles.title: Climate Change: we're doomed in ten years!
articles.author: Mike McDaniel
articles.summary: There is a long history of doomsday predictions about Earth's climate change. Donald Trump was elected and suddenly, Climate Change is on the back burner. The UN has admitted that even if all the money demanded to fight the climate crisis was spent, the global temperature might decrease by a fraction of a single centigrade in a century or so.

articles.title: Is Geoengineering Playing God With the Planet?
articles.author: Jan Otte
articles.summary: Geoengineering is the bold, controversial science of deliberately altering Earth's climate. Scientists are trying to save us from climate disaster, or are they playing God with our only home? What you're about to read may change the way you look at the sky forever.

articles.title: Will Climate Action Always Come Too Late to Matter?
articles.author: Atta Ur Rehman
articles.summary: The world's thermostat seems jammed on 'hotter', wildfires rage like angry dragons, and storms hit harder every year. Will climate action always be a step behind, or can we actually make a difference before it's too late? Let's dig deep, get real and find out what's true, what's hype, and where hope might still flicker.

articles.title: Kenya Met Issues Fresh Weather Warning
articles.author: Rene Otinga
articles.summary: Strong winds are to be expected in various parts of the country from Sunday to Tuesday, especially in the coastal waters. Two people went missing in Kilifi on Friday, May 23, after their vessel was hit by strong winds. Three boats capsized in Lamu and Kilifi over the weekend. Mombasa governor ordered the closure of the beaches for two days.

articles.title: Hunters form unlikely alliance amid emerging threats to animals and traditions: 'It's the whole process of making everything right'
articles.author: Maris Toalson
articles.summary: Sea-level rise threatens migratory birds in the Down East region of North Carolina. 389 migratory bird species are at risk of extinction due to the effects of warming temperatures. The Down East has a history of commercial fishing, duck hunting, and duck decoy carving, among other activities.

articles.title: UAE Hits Record May Temperature Of 51.6C
articles.author: ETV Bharat
articles.summary: The highest ever temperature in the UAE was recorded at 51.6C in Sweihan (Al Ain) at 13:45 UAE local time (0945 GMT) on Saturday. The highest temperature recorded on Abu Dhabi's Al Yasat Island in 2010 was 52C. The UAE has just emerged from a record-breaking April with an average daily high of 42.6 Celsius.

articles.title: Experts warn of cascading impacts from record-low sea ice levels: '[Affects] coastal communities around the world'
articles.author: Amy Boyington
articles.summary: Melting sea ice is a global issue with far-reaching consequences. The Arctic has lost about 70% of its ice volume since the 1980s. In 2023, Antarctic sea ice levels will reach a 2,000-year low. Human actions affect the planet in ways that speed up sea ice melt.

articles.title: Dozens Missing After Three Boats Capsize Off Kenyan Coast Amid Storm Warnings
articles.author: Justus Kiprono
articles.summary: Several dozen people are missing after three boats capsized off Kenya's coast in Kilifi and Lamu counties on Saturday, May 24, 2025. The Kenya Red Cross is on the ground, supporting offshore response, medical evaluations, and lifeguard services. Several survivors were rescued and are receiving medical treatment, but rough waters are complicating efforts to locate those still missing.

articles.title: A real time working example of variable inputs and the hurricane season
articles.author: Joe Bastardi
articles.summary: According to Grok, the cooling of SST from 2024 to 2025 and the rapid drop-off in Mid-Ocean Spreading Zone Seismic Activity (MOSZSA) is likely a key factor in the observed temperature change. The decrease in magma upwelling along the Mid-Atlantic Ridge has reduced the heat input into the ocean, leading to cooler SSTs in 2025 compared to 2024. Most major hurricanes in the past decade have formed close to the coast and are closely tied to Madden-Julian Oscillation.

articles.title: Scientists make grim prediction after witnessing disturbing changes in Arctic conditions: 'It will affect both the mean and extremes'
articles.author: Alyssa Ochs
articles.summary: Melting sea ice in the Arctic region is leading to extreme rainfall and flooding in South Asia. According to NASA, summer Arctic sea ice is shrinking at a rate of 12.2% per decade due to warming global temperatures. Monsoon rains can have devastating effects on communities worldwide.

articles.title: Scientists sound alarm as unsettling phenomenon creeps across coastal communities: 'I had a house … now it is at the bottom of the sea'
articles.author: Mandy Carr
articles.summary: Latin America is still reeling from hurricanes Eta and Iota, which hit two weeks apart in 2020. Warming temperatures, droughts, floods, and rising sea levels are the main causes of climate change migration in Latin America and the U.S. One solution is to reduce dirty energy use and install solar panels on your home.

articles.title: Redfish Pointe is not 'responsible growth'
articles.summary: Redfish Pointe property owners want to change the city's future land use map to allow for development among wetlands in southwest Cape Coral. The property was purchased in the 1950's with property rights under Lee County jurisdiction. In the last few decades, Lee County has experienced explosive growth. Cape Coral is one of the nine cities in the nation most at risk from future storms.

articles.title: Three missing after boats capsize in strong Coast winds
articles.author: Maureen Ongala
articles.summary: Three people are missing in Kilifi and Lamu counties after their boats capsized due to the strong winds. In Kilifi, the whereabouts of two people remain unknown, while a woman was rescued from a boat incident. In Lamu, a fisherman has been reported missing while nine other sailors were rescued in two separate boat capsize incidents. The Kenya Meteorological Department has already sent out a warning for strong winds in the counties of Marsabit, Turkana, Samburu, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Kitui, Makueni, Taita Taveta, Tana River, Lamu and Mombasa.

articles.title: UAE records new high of 51.6 degrees Celsius in May
articles.author: Times News Service
articles.summary: Temperatures in the UAE reached 51.6 degrees Celsius at Sweihan in Al Ain on Saturday. This is a record for the country for this year so far. On 23rd May, another record high of 50.4 degrees Celsius was recorded in UAE.

articles.title: Warning America could face 1000ft ‘mega-tsunami'
articles.author: Isabel Keane
articles.summary: A study warns of a potential 1,000-foot-tall "mega tsunami" that could devastate parts of America if a major earthquake hits the Cascadia subduction zone within the next 50 years. Alaska, Hawaii, and the West Coast are most at risk due to the fault line stretching from Northern Vancouver Island to Cape Mendocino, California.

articles.title: CLIMATE CHANGE AND WE
articles.summary: There is an increase in CO2 emissions from fossil fuels and industry. The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has risen by 50% since the Industrial Revolution. Forests are the major sink for atmospheric carbon after oceans. Cutting of world's tropical forests, which provide a vital buffer against climate change, leads to savannisation.

articles.title: Municipalities Must Consider Climate Change in Comprehensive Planning Process
articles.author: Banker
articles.summary: As municipalities address long-term planning, the effects of climate change must be prioritized. Rising sea levels, frequent extreme weather events and degradation of natural ecosystems require a new approach that integrates climate resiliency into every aspect of planning for urban, suburban and rural communities. The relationship between land use, transportation and environmental impact is central to new planning strategies.

articles.title: It's about building Malta's resilience: Coastal and stormwater strategies for Vision 2050
articles.summary: Climate change is affecting Malta's coastal areas and contributing to more frequent flooding. The government is taking a proactive approach to mitigating the impacts of climate change on the country's environment, infrastructure and communities. The Coastal and Stormwater Directorate within the Department of Public Works has spearheaded a national flood relief infrastructure project (EU funded) that addresses stormwater management through a network of underground tunnels, canals and bridges. The strategy also includes the expansion and rehabilitation of existing reservoirs to facilitate rainwater harvesting.

articles.title: Climate Cash Crisis: Can Investment Planning Fix Europe's Finance Adaptation Gap?
articles.author: Maria Chourdaki
articles.summary: There is a climate change adaptation finance gap across the European Union. The AIC offers a framework for regions to effectively plan and secure the vital funding needed to strengthen climate defences. In the Caribbean, inaction on climate change could cost the region US$11 billion by 2025 and US$22 billion by 2050. In Europe, weather and climate-related extremes caused losses totalling €738 billion between 1980 and 2023.

articles.title: Why Iceland is becoming a glacier graveyard
articles.author: Luigi Jorio
articles.summary: Iceland has lost 70 of its 400 glaciers in the last 25 years. The Okjökull Glacier in the centre of Iceland was declared 'dead' in 2014. Glaciers cover about 11% of Iceland's land area. The glacier meltwater is used to generate hydroelectric power.

articles.title: It's about building Malta's resilience: Coastal and stormwater strategies for Vision 2050
articles.author: The Malta Independent
articles.summary: Climate change is increasingly impacting Malta's coastal areas and contributing to more frequent flooding across the islands. The Government of Malta is determined to address this rapidly evolving situation through forward-thinking and forward-looking measures.    .   i   in Malta.

articles.title: No more grandstanding: Deforestation pledges will burn in flames if we ignore inequality
articles.author: Chris Wright
articles.summary: Wildfires destroyed 6.7 million hectares of tropical primary forest last year. It's the largest area of fire-related tropical forest loss ever recorded. Boris Johnson launched a landmark global forestry pledge in Glasgow to halt and reverse forest loss by 2030. The pledge to end deforestation by 2030 is not a lost cause. In order to protect forests, governments need to empower indigenous peoples.

articles.title: Highest class solar flare registered on Sunday
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: The highest class solar flare of the highest class was registered in the Sun on Sunday. The flare lasted for 17 minutes and was in the X-ray band within the group of spots 4098 (S05W22). It is accompanied with solar plasma ejections. Its clouds may provoke magnetic storms when reaching Earth.

articles.title: Rescue Operations in Australian Floods: Helicopters Airdrop Animal Feed
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Helicopters delivered animal feed to farmers cut off by the flooding in southeast Australia. Five people died and tens of thousands were affected by the disaster. Experts link Australia's extreme weather to climate change. There have been a series of droughts and bushfires in recent years.

articles.title: Flood-weary regions brace for high winds amid clean up
articles.author: Maeve Bannister
articles.summary: More challenging weather conditions lie ahead for crews battling to protect coastal regions stricken by floods, says the National Weather Service, which is concerned about the weather forecast for coastal regions affected by floods.    .   i   for more information, visit weather.gov.uk.

articles.title: Zombie Apocalypse? The fungus that eats you alive is coming, and climate change just gave it a passport
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Global warming is exacerbating the threat of deadly fungal infections, particularly those caused by Aspergillus species, according to a recent study.    .      "Fungal infections are getting worse because of global warming."

articles.title: Devon butterfly recorder warns of concerning species decline
articles.author: Chloe Parkman
articles.summary: Butterfly Conservation said the number of four species of butterfly in Devon were at their lowest for at least a decade in 2024. The charity's Devon branch recorder, Pete Hurst, said humans had "destroyed wildlife habitats" and said poor weather meant "already depleted" populations were vulnerable and unable to bounce back.

articles.title: Over 100 electric poles damaged as storm hits Sirsa; power outage continues
articles.author: Anil Kakkar
articles.summary: Sirsa was hit by a powerful storm on Saturday night. The storm caused widespread damage to the environment and power infrastructure. Over 100 electricity poles were damaged and some high-tension lines destroyed. The Dakshin Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam (DHBVN) is assessing the full extent of the damage.

articles.title: Cold, wet and windy night, shepherd's fright: How a BoM warning saves Aussie sheep
articles.author: Cameron Carr
articles.summary: Sheep grazier warnings are issued by the Bureau of Meteorology to warn farmers about upcoming cold or wet conditions that could harm their livestock. The alerts are most often sent to farmers in southwest Western Australia, southern South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and much of NSW.

articles.title: Bear activity picking up in Greater Sudbury; city advises caution
articles.author: Star Staff
articles.summary: The Report-a-Bear initiative has received more reports of bear activity this April after a quiet winter. The potential for human-bear interactions increases in the spring when there are fewer natural food sources available. To prevent a bear from visiting your property, put away winter bird feeders, seed and suet, clean outdoor barbecue grills after each use and keep dogs leashed.

articles.title: Coastal Zone Management Plan Goa CZMP 2019 tourism input CRZ 2011 regulations
articles.author: Herald Team
articles.summary: Goa's Tourism Department has to submit a tourism management plan for integration into the Coastal Zone Management Plan (CZMP) 2019. The CZMP was approved in September 2022, but discrepancies emerged when the maps were overlaid with the updated cadastral (Bhunaksha) plans. The Kerala-based National Centre for Earth Science Studies (NCESS) is responsible for preparing the CZ MP 2019. Goa remains the only one among India's 11 coastal states yet to finalize its plan.

articles.title: The scorching new normal in Pakistan
articles.author: Nabil Tahir
articles.summary: In 2025, temperatures in Shaheed Benazirabad sweltered at 50°C, 8.5 degrees above the seasonal norm, Rahim Yar Khan, Jacobabad, and Turbat were baking under 48°C heat, while parts of Balochistan hit 49°C in April. Scientists have traced this deadly heat back to its root cause – the accelerating rise in global temperatures driven by human activity. The 2022 spring heatwave that swept across India and Pakistan was made roughly 30 times more likely by greenhouse gas-driven climate change.

articles.title: UAE breaks May heat record again
articles.author: The National
articles.summary: The UAE broke a May temperature record for the second day in a row on Saturday. The mercury rose to 51.6°C in the Sweihan area close to Al Ain. The previous May record of 50.2°C was set in May 2009. It comes after the UAE experienced the hottest April on record. The National Centre of Meteorology has issued a heat warning.

articles.title: BBC Warming Arctic Claims Are Fake News
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: BBC report claims that the Arctic is warming four times faster than anywhere else. The Arctic is not warming at all. In fact, temperatures in the Arctic have been stable for the last two decade. In the 1930s and 40s there was a plunge in temperatures, followed by a recovery. We see the same pattern in northern Norway.

articles.title: I Explored Litchfield National Park—And Found Australia's Hidden Natural Wonder
articles.author: Kalpana Sunder
articles.summary: Litchfield National Park in Australia is full of fascinating wildlife. Kookaburras and kingfishers fly past as the canopy provides shade and a cool temperature. Grey-headed flying foxes can travel up to 50 km in the night, pollinating flowers and spreading fruit seeds.

articles.title: Early warning systems: Bridging tech and tradition to protect communities
articles.author: Hellen Shikanda
articles.summary: Kenya has made significant progress in developing early warning capabilities in the past decade. Kenya's indigenous communities have long relied on environmental indicators to forecast weather events. The department is transitioning to an "Impact-Based Early Warning System" that considers both hazards and vulnerabilities.

articles.title: The top 9 grilling mistakes and how to fix them
articles.author: Elizabeth Karmel
articles.summary: I love to grill and barbecue. I have devoted my career to outdoor cooking for more than two decades. I put together a list of the biggest grilling don'ts and how to avoid them. Print this list and refer to it the next time you get ready to grill.

articles.title: UAE bakes at 51.6°C as May heatwave scorches streets, strains air cons and stuns residents
articles.summary: The United Arab Emirates has broken its May temperature record for the second day in a row, hitting 51.6 degrees Celsius on Saturday. The highest temperature recorded in the UAE since documentation began in 2003 was reported at 52°C on Abu Dhabi's Al Yasat Island in 2010. The desert nation lies in one of the planet's hottest regions and is vulnerable to climate change.

articles.title: These 12 States Face a Surge in Mosquito-Borne Illness
articles.author: Ayman Rani Ahmed
articles.summary: The world is heating up, storms are stronger, and wildfires rage with a fury. For weather enthusiasts, it's both fascinating and terrifying. Will our efforts to fight climate change always arrive too late to make a real difference? Let's dig into the facts, the emotion, and the science behind this high-stakes chase.

articles.title: Researchers alarmed over declining bird populations
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: Bird populations are declining across every habitat, but the worst declines are in birds' habitats, according to the researchers.    "There are declining bird populations in every habitat but in the worst-hit areas. "   "There is a decline in bird's habitats.

articles.title: Rescue Helicopters Feed Stranded Farmers Amid NSW Flood Catastrophe
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Flooding in Australia's New South Wales has claimed five lives and isolated tens of thousands. Helicopters were deployed on Sunday to airlift emergency feed to farmers stranded by rising waters. In recent years, Australia has experienced increased extreme weather events, a trend some attribute to climate change.

articles.title: Carolina Hurricanes vs. Florida Panthers FREE LIVE STREAM (5/24/25)
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Carolina Hurricanes face the Florida Panthers in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals of the 2025 NHL Stanley Cup playoffs on Saturday, May 24, 2025 (5/24/25) at Amerant Bank Arena in Sunrise, Florida. Carolina Hurricanes won the game 2-1.

articles.title: EPA issues burn off warning
articles.author: jimjin
articles.summary: EPA Victoria is warning the agricultural sector not to mix their prunings and felled timber with other types of waste. EPA can issue fines of more than $9,000 for mixing waste into their legitimate burn off material. The EPA's guide on farm waste management is available at: epa.vic.gov.au/about-epa/publications/iwrg641-1.

articles.title: Zombie Apocalypse? The fungus that eats you alive is coming, and climate change just gave ...
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: Global warming is exacerbating the threat of deadly fungal infections, particularly those caused by Aspergillus species, according to a recent study.    .      "Fungal infections are getting worse because of global warming."

articles.title: Potential oil spill threatens Kerala\u2019s southern coast after container ship capsizes
articles.author: Indian Express
articles.summary: The areas identified as most vulnerable include Alappuzha, Ambalapuzha and Arattupuzha. The areas are also known as Karunagappally, Arattuppuzha or Arattuvanthu. The area is located in the southern part of Kerala.

articles.title: Letters for May 25: Region needs to work together to fight climate change
articles.author: Daily Press
articles.summary: The Virginian-Pilot and Daily Press Editorial Board wrote an editorial about global warming and the weather warning in Tidewater. The editorials were published on May 11. The Republican thanks them for their editorial. It was well-written and stated the situation clearly.

articles.title: Genghis Khan Killed Enough People To Cool The Planet
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: Genghis Khan's armies killed as many people as his genitals. Genghis may have inadvertently sequestered huge amounts of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Only the Mongol invasion can compensate for concurrent emissions from the rest of the world, according to the author.

articles.title: 'Climate risk' hype overstates threats: Real culprits are real estate growth and density
articles.author: Natural News
articles.summary: NOAA data shows no long-term trends in hurricane or fire insurance premiums. Real estate growth, not climate change, is to blame for insurance costs rising, according to the NOAA data.    for a new analysis by NOAA data shows that there is no trend in hurricane insurance premiums rising.

articles.title: Dwindling funds, shrinking strength
articles.author: Olli-Pekka Kuusela
articles.summary: As global temperatures rise and climate-related disasters become more frequent, the need to adapt is increasing. The need for adaptation is most acute in low- and middle-income countries such as Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Haiti and Vietnam. Several rich countries have cut their development aid budgets in the past three years. This shift could undermine the climate finance commitments made by wealthy countries to mobilise $300 billion (£228 billion) a year for climate action by 2035.

articles.title: Why Iceland is becoming a glacier graveyard
articles.author: Swissinfo
articles.summary: Iceland's glaciers are among the fastest-melting ice sheets in the world. The northern European island nation has lost 70 of its 400 glaciers. The sea and land are rising as a result, with consequences for tourism and shipping. The rate of glacial mass loss in Iceland is among the world's highest.

articles.title: Snowy owl's threatened status an "alarm bell" for a changing Arctic, scientist says
articles.author: North Shore News
articles.summary: The Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife In Canada assesses the snowy owl as threatened. Snowy owls nest in a region with one of the fastest-changing climates on the planet. They also face collisions, electrocution, rodenticide poisoning, and diseases like avian influenza.

articles.title: Decarbonizing Steel Is Tough As Steel
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: The long-term aspirational goal of the Paris Agreement on climate change is to cap global warming at the level agreed to by the Paris parties.       in the Paris agreement is to limit global warming to below 2°C. In the

articles.title: Why a remote small city is now New Zealand's most expensive place to rent
articles.author: Stuff
articles.summary: Gisborne is the most expensive place to rent in Aotearoa. It's rising in the east, but it's a crown no one wants, because people don't want to rent there anymore.    i.e. in Gisborne.

articles.title: Heatwave fuels skin related ailments
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: The ongoing heatwave across South Punjab has triggered a rise in skin-related ailments. Dermatologists warn of complications caused by excessive sweating and prolonged exposure to high temperatures. Dr Waqas Arqam Malik, a noted dermatologist, noted this fact.

articles.title: Florida bill would ban ‘chemtrails' and ‘geoengineering.' But what are they?
articles.author: Sun Sentinel
articles.summary: Gov. Ron DeSantis recently signed into law a ban on 'weather modification activities' such as spreading tiny particles into the air from aircraft to control sunlight. There are long-standing controversies over 'geoengineering' and 'chemtrails' in Florida.

articles.title: Regional solidarity for disaster preparedness
articles.author: Abrar H Hashmi
articles.summary: The Himalaya–Karakoram–Hindukush (HKH) region is undergoing profound transformations due to climate change. The HKH region is shared by eight countries and has 55,000 glaciers that feed major rivers such as the Indus, Ganges, Yangtze and the Yarlung Tsangpo–Brahmaputra. If global temperatures continue on their current trajectory, up to 80 percent of glacier volume in the HKH could vanish by the end of this century. Pakistan is home to the Himalayas, the Karakoram and the Hindukush ranges and boasts more than 7,000 Glaciers. The glaciers are crucial for Pakistan
